title: 112_hr4234
content: The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2012" is the short title of this Act. It pertains to the terms of grazing permits and leases. Section 402 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 is amended to extend the time period from "ten years" to "20 years" for grazing allotments, permits, or leases. Additionally, it includes provisions related to the initial environmental analysis under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. The amendment extends the time period for grazing allotments, permits, or leases from "ten years" to "20 years" under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. It also includes a provision stating that the initial environmental analysis under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 has not been completed. SEC. 405 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 amends the time period for grazing permits and leases from "ten years" to "20 years." It also addresses the completion of the initial environmental analysis under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. In this section, "current grazing management" refers to grazing based on existing permits or leases, with modifications consistent with relevant resource management plans. "Secretary concerned" is defined as the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System land and the Secretary of the Interior for other lands. The term 'Secretary concerned' refers to the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System land and the Secretary of the Interior for other lands. Grazing permits or leases issued by these Secretaries that expire, transfer, or are waived must be renewed or reissued under section 402. Grazing permits or leases issued by the Secretary of the Interior or Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System land that expire, transfer, or are waived must be renewed or reissued under specific sections of relevant acts. The terms and conditions of expired, transferred, or waived grazing permits or leases under specific acts will continue until the renewed or reissued permit or lease is processed by the Secretary concerned. The Secretary concerned must process renewed or reissued permits or leases under specific acts until completion, in compliance with applicable laws. Permits or leases described may be cancelled, suspended, or modified according to the law. The Secretary concerned may renew or reissue permits or leases for a term of 20 years after processing. The renewal, reissuance, or transfer of grazing permits or leases may be categorically excluded from environmental assessment requirements. The Secretary may renew grazing permits for 20 years without environmental assessment if current management meets objectives. The Secretary may renew grazing permits for 20 years without environmental assessment if current management meets objectives or is consistent with department policy. The priority and timing for completing environmental analyses are at the discretion of the Secretary concerned. The Secretary has the discretion to determine the priority and timing for completing environmental analyses for grazing allotments, permits, or leases based on environmental significance and available funding. NEPA exemptions include crossing and trailing authorizations of domestic livestock and transfer of grazing preference. The National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 exemptions include crossing and trailing authorizations of domestic livestock and transfer of grazing preference. Sec. 405 addresses the renewal, transfer, and reissuance of grazing permits and leases.
